text: The famous red awning with COPACABANA in white block lett hangs over the entrance of the world-renowned nightclub. long line of well-dressed customers fills the sidewalk waiting to get in. OVER THIS - WE HEAR the opening horns of Bobby Rydell’s version of “THAT OLD BLACK MAGIC”...

The vibe is electric. SIX HUNDRED PATRONS pack the tables the main room. Brazilian in theme, the Copa décor is art throughout, filled with palm trees illuminated by blue an pink hues. Pure elegance. Peppering the crowd... gorgeous COPA GIRLS, white-jackete WAITERS, MAITRE D’S in Black Tuxedo Jackets, CAPTAINS in Tux Jackets, and BOUNCERS in Red Tux Jackets. On stage in front of the Orchestra, tuxedo-clad BOBBY RYD The crowd APPLAUDS.

Thank you very much! Welcome to Jules Podell’s Copacabana! I’m Bobby Rydell and I’m happy to be here! (singing) That old Black Magic has me in its spell... THE SONG CONTINUES THROUGH THIS ENTIRE SEQUENCE... FRANK “TONY LIP” VALLELONGA, 40s, Copa bouncer, moves qui through the crowd. Lip is imposing with a charismatic presence. You don’t mess with this guy. Following Lip, an ATTRACTIVE COUPLE. Lip leads them to a table near the front of the stage. The man slips Lip some cash. The Orchestra kicks in big, the room is jumping... At a back booth, JULES PODELL, 60, Copa owner, a tough-as nails bulldog of a man. He taps his diamond ring on the t to the beat of the song.

Lip trolls for customers who will tip him for a table. He NOTICES... JOEY LOSCUDO, 50s, a Mob Boss, entering the club followed his CREW. Loscudo walks over to the COAT-CHECK GIRL, take off his coat and hat, hands them to her.
Guard this hat with your life... My mother gave it to me. He winks.
Yes, Mr. Loscudo... He hands the Coat-Check Girl some money. The MAITRE D’, CARMINE, walks over.
Joey!
Hey, Carmine! Carmine slips Lip some cash.
That’s not necessary...
Come on. You know I saw this kid Rydell last year in Philly. Nobody knew who he was.
Well they know him now... They hug, then Carmine escorts Loscudo and his ENTOURAGE the main room. Lip approaches the Coat-Check Girl.
Gimme Loscudo’s hat.
But he said...
I know, just give it to me... He bangs her a couple bucks, she turns the hat over to hi
RYDELL’S STILL SINGING, THE JOINT’S ROCKING... A FIGHT br out... FOUR GOOMBAHS pound each other. Tables flip, glass breaks, patrons scream... ANGLE ON Podell as he jumps up...

Lip is already on the move, running to the fight... It’s pandemonium, but Rydell doesn’t stop. He and the Orchestra building the speed and intensity of the song... Lip is joined by Carmine, and some BOUNCERS, all of them grappling with the Goombahs. They quickly RUSH THEM OUT O THE ROOM....
Everyone comes CRASHING out the front door. Lip throws th Goombah down the steps to the street. He jumps up.

head_text.subj: YOU PUT YOUR HANDS ON ME, YOU

text: Do yourself a favor--go home with your friends.
Don’t you tell me where to go! Do you know who I am?! I’m goin’ back in there!

Nah, you’re not. The Goombah TAKES A SWING at Lip and it’s on. Lips KNOCKS ON HIS ASS, then jumps on him and starts to BASH HIS FACE CLOSE ON - Lip, brutally punching, his fists bloody, as W HEAR O.S. APPLAUSE and
The band’s swinging as Bobby Rydell delivers the big clim to the song... (CONTINUED)
(singing) .--Whoa, that old Black Magic called looocooccocve!
A line of people wait behind mob boss Joey Loscudo as he screams at the Coat-Check Girl. Carmine stands by.
I‘1l burn this place down! Where's my hat!
I’m sorry, Mr. Loscudo, I went to the ladies room, I was only gone a minute...
Someone better find it!
It‘ll turn up, I swear it’ll turn up.
Really? You tell that fat Jew bastard Podell that if it doesn’t turn up, I'll burn this place down! You hear me? I’ll burn the Copa down!

Lip, Carmine, and another bouncer, DANNY, smoke cigarette lean against a dinged-up ‘55 BUICK Sedan. A poster at the Copa entrance reads: BOBBY RYDELL - SOLD A worker pastes a banner over it: COPA CLOSED FOR RENOVAT NOVEMBER/DECEMBER -— SEE YOU IN JANUARY WITH SAMMY DAVIS,
Jesus Christ. Loscudo is out of his mind.
We earned our money tonight. (CONTINUED)
Lip, I thought you were gonna kill that guy.
Better him than me. What are you gonna do while we're closed?
I don’t know. Maybe work at my Uncle’s pizza joint.
(to Carmine) What about you?
I’m gonna drink for two months. The men straighten up as Jules Podell exits the club.
Take me home, Lip.
INT. JILLY’S SALOON - NIGHT LOSCUDO’S HAT GETS PLOPPED IN THE MIDDLE OF A TABLE... PULL BACK... Luscudo sits in the corner booth, holding co with JILLY and friends.
My hat! Jesus Christ, if you had tits, I’d kiss ya! How the hell’d you find it? ANGLE ON LIP standing in front of the table.
Heard it was missing, so I looked into it.
I wanted to kill that broad.
Wasn't her fault.
Who had the balls to clip it? (CONTINUED)
Don’t worry about it, I took care of him.
I hope you gave him some beating. Loscudo pulls out a wad of cash, peels off a C-note.
No, I can’t. It was my pleasure, Mr. Loscudo. Loscudo SLAMS the MONEY into Lip’s hand.

Bullshit. And from now on you don’t have to call me Mister Loscudo, ya hear me? Lip smiles. EXT. LIP’S APARTMENT - BRONX - DAWN A six-story brick building with fire escapes framing the windows. Parked cars fill both sides of the street. Lip’s pulls up and parks in front of a FIRE HYDRANT. He gets ou grabs a garbage can, and PUTS IT OVER THE HYDRANT. INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - MORNING Lip ENTERS the small one-bedroom apartment. He moves to t kitchen, opens the refrigerator, chugs half a bottle of m INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM - MORNING Lip ENTERS. Sleeping in the bed, Lip’s wife DOLORES, late 30s, pretty. Beside her, NICK, 9, and FRANKIE, 7. Lip takes off a ring, his watch, places them on top of th bureau. Empties his pockets of crumpled wads of cash. Lip strips down to a t-shirt and boxer shorts, gets in be snuggles up to Dolores. She wakes, kisses him.
‘Morning...
‘Night...  INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - DAY

head_text.subj: FRANCISCO GIANTS, GAME 6 OF THE WORLD SERIES.

text: “Roger Maris at the plate, Pierce checks the signs...” PULL BACK -- On the couch watching the game, Lip’s Father NICOLA, 70s, brother RUDY, 30s, Dolores’ father, ANTHONY, 70s, and her two brothers JOHNNY, 40s, and LOUIE, 30s.
Come on, Roger! Hit one out!
Be quiet, you’re gonna jinx it! Lip ENTERS still wearing his t-shirt and white boxers.
(sarcastic) Johnny, think you can yell a little louder?
Maris is up...

Yeah, so am I now. What the hell are you guys doing here? Johnny discreetly nods toward the kitchen where we see TW BLACK WORKMEN laying down linoleum. The kids, Nick and Fr play with plastic Green Army soldiers in the corner.
Figured we'd come up and keep Dolores company... BACK TO SCENE - Lip gets the point.
(in Italian) You shouldn’t be sleeping in the middle of the day, leaving my daughter here alone with these sacks of coal.
(in Italian) And why do you hire them to do an Italian’s job? It’s a disgrace. (CONTINUED)
(in Italian) I don’t know who they’re gonna send. ON Dolores - she pours a couple glasses of lemonade and h the drinks to the Black Workmen.
Thank you, ma’am. Lip watches as the Workmen drink the lemonade, then Dolor takes the glasses and PUTS THEM IN THE SINK. As she leads men to the door, we go...

“Deep to center field, holy cow he did it! A home run for Roger Maris! Holy cow!” Johnny jumps up, they all CHEER... Except Lip, whose eyes keep darting toward the GLASSES IN SINK. Dolores comes back and Lip joins her in the kitchen pours himself a glass of water, dips his finger in the sa she’s cooking. Dolores slaps his hand away.

Get dressed, Tony, we’re gonna eat. She picks up a big platter of meatballs and sausage and t it into the dining room. Lip glances into the sink. CLOSE ON - The Black Workmen’s two empty lemonade glasses Lip takes the GLASSES out of the sink, DROPS THEM INTO TH GARBAGE.

INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - DINETTE - LATER Lip’s at the table, dressed now. Wine and plates of rigat Joining them for lunch are FRAN, Johnny's wife, and LYNN, Louie’s wife. Dolores makes the sign of the cross.
Bless us our Lord, for these thy gifts, which we are about to receive, from thy bounty through Christ our Lord, Amen. (CONTINUED)
They all make the sign of the cross.
Salute. They start stuffing their faces.
If anyone hears about a job for Tony, let us know.
(nobody's business) Dolores...
What happened, you get fired?
No, Copa’s closing for repairs. He needs something for just a couple months.
I’1l ask around.
(in Italian) Mister big shot. Always spend, spend, spend. No job, he gets himself a new kitchen floor.
(in Italian) Come on, Pop. The kids were gettin’ splinters in their feet.
All the people he knows, he'll find something.
He had a great job at the sanitation department. (to Lip) You shouldn’t have punched out the foreman.
He shouldn’t have woke me up. Everyone LAUGHS.

INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - KITCHEN - DAY - LATER Dolores is cleaning up. She’s scraping a plate into the garbage can when she notices something 0O.S. DOLORES’ POV - Two empty glasses in the garbage... She SIGHS, disappointed in her husband, then picks up the glasses from the garbage pail and puts them back into the sink.
INT. GORMAN’S HOT DOGS - DAY Johnny, Lip, and Lip’s youngest boy, Frankie, ENTER.
I’m tellin’ you, this is gonna be the easiest fifty bucks you ever made. They walk over to a table where FAT PAULIE, 40s, is waiti with the owner, GORMAN, and a couple other CUSTOMERS.
Johnny told me you ate forty-eight White Castle burgers in one sitting.
Cheeseburgers.
I don’t believe you.
What do I care if you believe me? (beat) Gorman, who’s got the record for hotdogs here?
Fat Paulie. Fifteen.
Why wasn’t Lip in on that contest?
What contest? I was hungry. The guys CHUCKLE. (CONTINUED)
Bet’s simple. Half a C-note. Most hotdogs in an hour wins. With toppings. Lip sizes him up.
What the hell you weigh?
Two-sixty.
Aaaaay. Your left ass weighs two- sixty. Fat Paulie raises his right hand.
May my mother-in-law drop dead on the spot if I’m lyin’. They all LAUGH.
Okay, you’re on.
INT. GORMAN’S HOT DOGS - LATER The table filled with an assortment of hot dogs. Everyone CHEERS, CLAPS, as Lip and Fat Paulie STUFF THEIR FACES.
Come on, Lip, pick it up! The baby elephant just hit nineteen! Lip sweats, slows down, looks like he’s gonna puke. The c cheers as Fat Paulie calmly takes a big bite of another d
INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - DAY Lip and Frankie ENTER. Frankie runs over to Nick who is d homework.
Nicky, you doin’ your homework? (CONTINUED)
Yeah.
Where were you? Lip plops down in a chair, exhausted.
Gorman’s. Fat Paulie bet me fifty bucks he could eat more hot dogs than me. He knocked off twenty- eight. Guy’s an animal.
Are you crazy--you lost fifty dollars?!
Dolores, please. I ate thirty. 12. Lip pulls out the winnings. She plucks the bills from his hand.
Thank God. The gas bill came in today. THE PHONE RINGS. Lip answers.
Yeah?
Jules Podell sits at his table in the empty Copa. He sips a cup of coffee as WORKERS clear tablecloths, flip chairs o tables, etc.
(into phone) Hey, Lip, some guy called over here -- a doctor’s lookin’ for a driver. You interested?
Yeah.
They're interviewing guys tomorrow afternoon. Here’s the address.  13.
Lip, wearing black slacks and a bowling-style shirt, stan at the front of... CARNEGIE HALL... He takes out a piece of paper, looks at it. This can’t be place...
Magnificent. Lip enters, moves down the aisle. He takes i the spectacle. WOMAN’S VOICE (0O.S.) Excuse me. We’re not open right now... Lip turns to face the BOX OFFICE MANAGER across the room.
But you’re welcome to buy tickets to tonight's performance.
‘There a doctor's office ‘round here? I think I got the wrong address. Lip holds up the paper.

You have the correct address. Dr. Shirley lives upstairs, above the hall. INT. DON SHIRLEY’S APARTMENT HALLWAY - DAY Lip walks down the hall. Two ENGLISH BUTLER-TYPES sit in chairs outside a door. The door opens and an ASIAN MAN, b suit and tie, carrying a briefcase, exits. At the door stands an Indian valet, AMIT, white Nehru shi white linen pants, clipboard in hand.
I'm here for the driver job. Tony Lip. Amit checks the list, flips a page, can’t find it.
I should be on there. (CONTINUED)
No Tony Lip. I do have a Tony Val...Valle...
Vallelonga. That’s me.
Fill this out while you wait.
What?
Fill. It. Out. While you wait. Amit hands him a clipboard and a pen, then Lip takes a se next to the butlers. INT. SHIRLEY’S APARTMENT - DAY - LATER Amit escorts Lip in. CLASSICAL MUSIC PLAYS.

Take a seat. Lip sits in a leather chair and Amit EXITS. Lip looks aro Never seen anything like it. Thirty-foot ceilings, giant skylight, enormous French windows overlooking Manhattan. It's filled to the rafters with paintings, African art, sculptures, Chinese lanterns, a giant gold Buddha, and tw six-foot elephant tusks. A crystal chandelier hangs above black Steinway Concert Grand Piano. A THRONE... an actual King’s throne... sits on a riser, b against the glass window.

Mr. Vallelonga, sorry to keep you waiting... Lip turns...Standing before him is DR. DONALD SHIRLEY, la 30s, black, resplendent in a traditional African robe. He bedecked in assorted chain necklaces, bracelets, watch, a rings. Dr. Shirley speaks in a clipped, refined manner.
I’m Dr. Donald Shirley. Lip’s taken aback. Not what he expected. He stands. (CONTINUED)
Hi. Tony. Shirley extends his hand. They shake.
Please, have a seat. Lip sits. Shirley sits on his “throne,” looking down at L
This is some place you got here. Motioning to the Elephant Tusks.
Them horns real?
Elephant tusks. Yes. Lip nods, points to the chain around Shirley’s neck.
What about that? That a molar?
A what?
A molar. Lip points to his side teeth.
Like a shark tooth? Or a tiger's?
Um, no. It was a gift.
Oh. (looks around) I thought I was going to an office. They said a doctor needed a driver.
That’s all they told you? Lip shrugs. (CONTINUED)
Actually, it’s a bit more complicated than that. Have you ever driven professionally before?
Sanitation. (beat) Garbage trucks. Off Shirley’s unimpressed look.
Plus I drive my boss home at night. I can drive anything.
I see. What other experience do you have?
I worked a lot of joints. The Wagon Wheel, Peppermint Lounge, Copa...
In what capacity?
What do you mean?
What did you do there? Lip chews on that. You can smell the wood burning...
Public relations... Shirley nods, understanding.
Well, first of all, Tony, I’m nota medical doctor. I’m a musician.
You mean like songs?
Yes. I’m about to start a concert tour, the majority of which will be down South.
Atlantic City? (CONTINUED)

The deep south. We start in the midwest, but then we’re taking a hard left. Kentucky, North Carolina, Tennessee, and on down through the Delta. (beat) Do you foresee any issues working for a black man?
No, no... ‘fact just yesterday me and the wife had a couple colored guys over the house. For drinks. Shirley takes a BEAT.
Oh, I see. You’re married.
Yup. Two kids.
I don’t know if this is the proper job for a married man.
Why, we bringing broads? Shirley shoots him a look.
My point is, you’ll be gone for eight straight weeks--with no breaks--right up until Christmas. You're quite sure you can leave your family for that long?
Depends on what you’re paying.

Ninety dollars a week, plus room and board. But let me be crystal clear... I’m not simply hiring a chauffeur. I need someone who can handle my itinerary. I need a personal assistant. I need a valet. I need someone who will launder my clothes, shine my shoes...
Good luck, Doc. (CONTINUED)
Lip stands, heads for the door. Shirley steps down off hi throne.
Tony... Lip turns back, faces Shirley.

I had my record label ask around town to find me the right man. Your name came up more than once. You’ve impressed a lot of people by the way you handle... trouble. That’s why I called and asked about your availability. Lip thinks about it.

Look, I got no problem being on the road with you. But I ain’t no butler, I ain’t ironing shirts, and I’m not shining nobody's shoes. You need someone to get you from point A to point B? You need someone to make sure there’s no problems along the way -- and you going through the deep South, believe me, there's gonna be problems. So if you want me, it’s gotta be a buck and a quarter a week. Or go hire the little Chink that just pranced out of here and see how far you get. Shirley stares, stone-faced.
Well, Mr. Vallelonga...thank you for coming in. As Lip turns and walks out, we --
A tired Lip comes walking down the sidewalk and ENTERS.
Smoky, packed, loud... Lip snakes his way to BOBBY, 40s, CHINESE, who’s behind the bar. (CONTINUED)
Bobby, give me a Rheingold. Ice cold. Bobby pours a draft of Rheingold, slides it in front of h
(concerned) Mister Tony. Augie asking about you. Lip isn’t happy to hear this. A CUSTOMER pounds on the ba
Come on, I’m dying of thirst over here!
Shut up, I’m talking! He turns back to Lip.
When?

Now. He in his box. Lip drains the beer, leaves the bar area, weaves his way through the crowd to an ENCLOSED, PRIVATE BOOTH with a curtain blocking the people inside. Lip hesitates, then o the curtain. HIS POV - AUGIE, rough-looking, dead eyes, sits there stuffing his face with linguini and clam sauce. TWO PSYCHOPATHS sit with him. The Psychos look on blankly. A lesser man would shit his pants.
(intense) Tony Lip. What the hell happened at the Copa? I heard you split a guy’s face open. Lip shrugs. AUGIE (CONT’D) That guy you hit. He was one of Charlie the Hand’s crew.
Then he shoulda known better. (CONTINUED)
Augie mad-dogs him, never losing eye contact as he stuffs face. Lip doesn’t blink.

The Hand wanted me to look into it. I spoke to Podell. Whole thing was over a piece of ass, right? Lip shrugs. AUGIE (CONT’D) A beef like that should never happen in the club. They were out of line. So we squashed it. He wipes olive oil off his chin. AUGIE (CONT’D) Sit down. Have something to eat.
Thanks, but I already ate. Augie chews away, not sure if he believes him.
You looking to earn some extra scharole? I could keep you busy while the Copa’s down.
What I gotta do?
Things... Lip thinks about it.
Appreciate it, but I’m gonna spend some time with the family.
Don’t be stupid. You can make a few bucks, buy something nice for your wife.
I’m good. I’m flush right now. cur
The EL TRAIN thunders above Lip as he enters a PAWN SHOP.
CLOSE ON Lip’s WRISTWATCH on the counter. The pawn guy, CHARLIE, looks up at Lip, concerned. Reluctantly, he hand Lip cash and a ticket.
Here's fifty. Give me sixty before Christmas, you get it back. Lip turns to leave. PAWN GUY (CONT’D) Hey, Lip... everything okay?
(offended) You got beak trouble, Charlie? Mind your business. Lip walks out. INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Lip sits watching TV as Dolores hands him a bowl of spagh
So what happened with the doctor interview?
He ain’t a real doctor, he’s a piano player. Lip digs in, starts stuffing his face.
I don’t understand--why’d they say he was a doctor?
I don’t know. I think he’s like a doctor of piano-playing or something.
You can be that? (CONTINUED)

I guess. He lives on top of Carnegie Hall. You shoulda seen this place, Dee--it was filled with statues and all kinds of fancy crap. And he was sitting on a friggin’ throne all dressed up like the king of the jungle bunnies.
He’s colored? You wouldn’t last a week with him.

For the right money, I would. As Lip continues eating, we go... INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - BEDROOM - EARLY MORNING Lip and Dolores are asleep in bed, the kids asleep in ano bed across the room. THE PHONE RINGS. Lip and Dolores wak up. Lip looks at the clock--8 a.m. He answers the phone.
(into phone) Hello... Yeah... Really?... Why?... Okay, hold on. Lip puts his hand over the receiver.
Everything okay?
It’s him.
Who?
Dr. Shirley, the piano guy. He wants to talk to you. She sits up.
(whispers) Me? What? Why? Lip shrugs. He holds out the phone, Dolores takes it. (CONTINUED)
(into phone) Hello... Good morning, Doctor, nice to talk to you, too... She glances at Lip.
(into phone) Yes, that is a long time... Dolores looks at Lip as Shirley talks on.
(beat) It is...Yes, I’m sure...Thank you for calling...Goodbye. Dolores hangs up.
What he say? Dolores looks stunned.
He wanted to know if I'd be okay with him taking my husband away from his family for two months. He said he'd pay you what you asked for. Lip looks surprised. She rolls away from him.
It’s good money, Dolores. You know we need it. I can’t be eatin’ thirty hot dogs every day. Dolores wells up.

I know...I said it was okay for you to go. EXT. LIP’S APARTMENT - MORNING Dion's “RUNAROUND SUE” drifts lazily from a transistor radio... Laundry hangs from fire escapes. OLD ITALIAN WOM sit in folding chairs CHATTING while Grandpa Nicola, Gran Anthony and Rudy watch Nick and Frankie play. A 1963 CHRYSLER NEW YORKER and a 1961 CADILLAC SEDAN are parked in front. (CONTINUED)
Lip, wearing a well-worn black suit, stands next to the Chrysler talking to a RECORD EXEC, 40s, sharply dressed, nonsense, and his nebbishy ASSISTANT. The Record Exec han Lip a check.
Here's the first half of your pay. You’1ll get the rest when the tour’s over.
Uh-uh, I gotta get paid every week.
Sorry, that’s not how the record company does it. Lip glares at him. RECORD EXEC (CONT’D) We gotta have some guarantee you’1ll finish the job.
Why the hell wouldn’t I finish the job? I took it, didn’t I? The Record Exec glances at his assistant, then back at Li

Then you’ve got nothing to worry about. The Exec holds out the car keys. As Lip reaches for them, Exec pulls them back. RECORD EXEC (CONT’D) Here’s the deal, Mr. Vallelonga. It’s your job to get Don to all his tour dates on time. If he misses any shows, you’re not getting your back-end. Lip takes the keys.
He’s not gonna miss any shows.
Good. And you’re going to need this. He hands Lip a small GREEN BOOK. (CONTINUED)

RECORD EXEC (CONT’D) It’s the book I told you about. Sometimes you're staying in the same hotels, and sometimes you’re not. As Lip glances at the book, we -- ANGLE ON Lip’s brother-in-law, Johnny, exiting the buildi He carries a suitcase over to the Cadillac. As the Record Exec and his assistant drive off in the Chrysler, Lip walks over to Johnny.
(re: Caddy) Madonne. This the new one?
The record company rented it. Lip opens the trunk, Johnny puts the suitcase in.
So what'd my sister say about you being gone for three weeks?
Eight weeks. Johnny smirks.
Yeah, right. Ten-to-one you slap the moolie out and come home under a month. Lip smiles, shoves Johnny. Dolores approaches with the ki
Come here. Say goodbye to your father. Nick and Frankie run to Lip, hug him. They get emotional.
Stop that. You gotta be big boys, take care of your mother... HE give the kids kisses, then they run away. (CONTINUED)
Did you go to the A-A-A for the maps?
The record guy gave me maps and directions with the itinerary thing. And this. Lip pulls out the small green book that the Record Exec g him.
(reading) The Negro Motorist Green-Book?
Lists all the places coloreds can stay down south. Like if you’re traveling while black.
Traveling while black?
Yeah. Like if you’re black but you gotta travel for some reason.
They got a special book for that?
I guess.
Did you pack an iron?
I ain’t lugging around no iron, Dee.
How you gonna keep your pants pressed?
I’1ll put ‘em under my mattress. Dolores takes Lip’s hand.
I want you to write me a letter every chance you get. (CONTINUED)
Aw, come on, Dee, I can’t write letters.
Take you five minutes. Promise me.
I can’t write, it’s embarrassing-- they ain’t gonna be no good.
It’s a lot cheaper than callin’ long distance, Tony. Promise me you'll write. Lip SIGHS.
Okay. I promise. I’1l try. She looks at him.
Yeah. Lip hugs and kisses her. He gives her the check.
Put this in the bank today. She takes it and hands him a brown paper bag.
I made a couple veal-cutlet sandwiches for you and Dr. Shirley. Be careful. I love you.
Love you, too.
You better be home at Christmas or don’t come home at all! As they kiss, Grandpa Nicola CALLS OUT to Lip:
(in Italian) He who arrives late has no bed! Lip waves goodbye to everyone. WE STAY ON Dolores as he drives away...  28.

Lip parks Shirley's rented Cadillac in front of an identi Cadillac, gets out, opens the trunk. Smoking next to the other Cadillac is OLEG MALAKHOV, 30s, Russian, wears glas and GEORGE DYER, 30s. Lip takes out a cigarette, is about to light it, then not Oleg smoking. He puts the cigarette back in the pack, the walks over to Oleg and George.
Bum a smoke? Oleg sizes Lip up, then reluctantly hands him a cigarette
I’m Tony. You the band?
(Russian accent) Oleg. Cello.

George. Bass. And we’re not a band, we're a trio. Dr. Shirley exits the building, impeccably dressed in a s suit. He’s followed by his valet, Amit, who awkwardly car three large pieces of Shirley’s EXPENSIVE LUGGAGE. Lip opens the back door of the car. Shirley gets in. Amit drops the bags he was carrying on the sidewalk. Shirley s in the back seat. Amit leans in, places a RED CASHMERE BLANKET over Shirley's legs.
Thank you, Amit.

Have a wonderful trip, Doctor. Amit shuts the car door. The luggage sits on the sidewalk between Lip and Amit. Lip smokes his butt, shoots Amit an ain’t my job" look. Standoff. Amit caves, picks up the three bags, one at a time, puts into the trunk. Lip SLAMS the trunk shut.  29.
BIRD’S-EYE VIEW of The Westside Highway in 1960’s Manhatt and the glistening Hudson River as the two Cadillacs cros the upper-level of the George Washington Bridge surrounde hundreds of period cars.
Dr. Shirley’s Cadillac drives west on Route 80, followed Oleg and George.

Lip’s driving fast, smoking faster. Shirley chokes on the blue haze filling the car, cracks his window. Lip reaches into the brown paper bag, pulls out a wax-pap wrapped sandwich with “Tony” written on it, peels back th foil. Veal cutlet and peppers sandwich on a loaf of Itali bread. Still smoking, Lip starts to eat.

Tony, when we arrive in a city, the first thing I’d like you to do is check the piano where I’m playing. Make sure it’s a Steinway as per my contract. Lip pulls out a pen, writes “STAIN WAY” on the map.
And could you see to it that I have a bottle of Cutty Sark in my room every night.
Every night? Lip smiles.
Well if you ever need any help with that...
I won't. And ten-and-two on the wheel, please. Tony loses the smile. Shirley slides over in his seat so he’s directly behind Lip. (CONTINUED)
Doc, I noticed on the itinerary thing there that the last show’s December 23rd.
Birmingham, yes. It’s a Christmas show.
Any way we could hit the road early the next morning so we could be back home in time for Christmas Eve?
We'll see. Could you please put the cigarette out?
Why?
Because I can’t breathe back here.
What are you talking about? Smoke’s going into my lungs. I’m doing all the work here.

Thank you. Lip thinks about it, defiantly takes one long last drag o the heater, then another, then finally FLICKS IT OUTSIDE. Lip rolls up his window, shoots a look at the second sandwich, “Dr. Shirley” written on it. FUCK THIS GUY. He opens it, stuffs Shirley’s sandwich in his mouth, looks straight ahead.
Oleg’s car speeds up, pulls next to Shirley’s Cadillac. O rolls down his window, motions to Shirley, who rolls down window. (CONTINUED)
(in Russian) Everything okay?
(in Russian) Yes. Everything's fine. Lip looks back over his shoulder, stunned to hear Shirley speaking in another language.
(in Russian) Good. We’ll meet you at the hotel in Pittsburgh.
(in Russian) Make a reservation for dinner. We'll rehearse immediately after. See you there. Oleg gives Lip the hairy eyeball, blows past him.
(to himself) Hell’s he looking at? Lip looks in the mirror at Shirley.
You speak German, huh?
That was Russian.

Yeah, I was stationed in Germany in the army. I can pick up a little of what you’re sayin’. Be careful, Krauts are all sneaks. Kennedy shoulda bombed ‘em when we had the chance--plus now them Cuban bastards. Shirley rolls his eyes.
Where they going anyway? Ain’t they supposed to be following us? (CONTINUED)
They have the itinerary. As long as they make it to the shows on time, I don’t worry and you shouldn’t either.
(offended) I ain’t worried about nothin’.
Lip and Shirley sit in a booth eating lunch. Shirley pick a tuna salad while Lip chows down on a pot roast. Shirley watches Lip, amazed at the ferocity with which he attacks meal.

Salty. Lip continues to stuff his face. Lip looks Lip feels

I’m saying it’s salty, and salt’s cheatin’. Any cook can make things salty. But to make it taste good without the salt, with just the other flavors, that’s the trick. See, when you-- (CONTINUED)
We should be going soon if we expect to get to Pittsburgh by dinner.
You know, when I was in the army I knew a guy from Pittsburgh, but he called it Titsburgh because he said all the girls there have big tits.

‘The hell I know? Guess we'll find out, huh? Lip goes back to his plate.
By the way, when you hired me, my wife went out bought one of your records--‘one about the orphans.
Orphans?

Orpheus.

Orpheus in the Underworld. It's based on a French Opera. And those kids on the cover? They were demons in hell.
No shit? Must of been naughty kids.
They've been driving awhile now. Lip starts to pull the c over to the side of the road.
What are you doing?
I gotta take a leak.
Here? Now?
What, you want me to piss my pants?

The Cadillac stops on the shoulder of the road next to so trees. Lip gets out, takes a few steps... then realizes h forgot something... INT. PENN-SHERATON HOTEL - LIP’S ROOM - NIGHT Lip wears a guinea T-shirt. He steps out of the bathroom, dries his hands with a towel, opens a sliding glass door leads to... EXT. Lip peers across the courtyard, finds Dr. Shirley sitting the patio outside his room, drink in hand, a half-empty bottle of Cutty beside him. Lip observes a moment, goes back into his room.

Take this for any incidentals we may need. If you want something for yourself, you don’t have to ask me, just make sure you keep the receipts. When it runs low, let me know. Lip nods. They walk towards the exit.

One more thing--we will be attending many events before and after the concerts, interacting with some of the wealthiest and most highly-educated people in the country. It is my feeling that your diction, as charming as it may be in the tri-state area, could use a bit of finessing.
Like you mean diction in what way?
In the only way the word “diction” is ever used.
(unsure) Okay...
Your intonation, inflection, choice of words--
Ayyyy, I got my own problems, I gotta worry what other people think about the way I talk?
There are simple techniques I can teach you that are quite effective. I can help you. (CONTINUED)
Lip is frustrated.
I don’t need no goddamn help. If people don’t like the way I talk, they can go take a shit.
The profanity is another issue.
A fanabla, why you breakin’ my balls?

Because you can do better. And here’s another thing--as guest of honor, I will be announced when I enter these intimate events. You will be announced as well. Vallelonga may be difficult to pronounce. I was thinking “Valle” would be more appropriate. Tony Valle. It’s short and simple.
Nuh-uh. If they got a problem with Vallelonga, they can call me Tony Lip. Shirley winces.
These are genteel people. That might be a little...worldly for them.
Then it’s Tony Vallelonga. All these high-class people that are so much smarter than me, with all their intelligence and speakin’ abilities, you’re telling me they can’t pronounce my name?
I’m just telling you, Valle will make things easier.
My last name is Vallelonga and I ain't changing it for nobody. They don't like it, they can shove it up their ass--I'1ll just wait outside. (CONTINUED)
Dr. Shirley considers this.
A sound compromise.

Tony! Lip turns to see Shirley at the end of the aisle of parke cars.

Lip scoops up his winnings, walks away to the crowd’s dis

I’ve been looking for you.

If you need extra money, next time, ask me.
It’s more fun winning it. They reach the Cadillac. Lip opens the back door.
What if you lost?
(smiles) Craps and cards, I don’t lose, Doc. I don’t lose.
And stooping down in the gravel throwing dice for pocket change makes you a winner?
What are you giving me shit for? Everybody was doin’ it. Shirley eyeballs Lip.

Let’s go. And wipe your knees, you've got dirt on them. Shirley gets in, pulls the car door shut. Lip, embarrasse brushes the dirt off his pants.

(reading) “I’m eating real good--hamburgers mostly--so don’t worry about me not eating good. We are doing lots of driving around, and we talk a lot in the car. I saw Dr. Shirley tonight play piano. He doesn’t play like a colored guy. He plays like Liberace but better and I ain’t lying. He’s like a genius I think. When I look at him in the rear-view mirror, I can tell he’s always thinking and working stuff out in his head, I guess that’s what geniuses do. But it don’t look fun to be that smart. I miss you very very much, Baby. Love, Tony. P.S.-- I told you I can’t write letters, ha ha! Regards to your father and brother. I’m going to get a haircut tomorrow. P.S.--Kiss Nickie and Frankie both for me.” As Dolores smiles, we --
Shirley's Cadillac drives along.

Lip drives. Next to him, a couple of maps, soda bottles, empty candy wrappers. Shirley sits comfortably in the bac reading glasses on the edge of his nose, reading Allan Drury’s A Shade of Difference. Lip fiddles with the radio, changing stations. Stops on t song Lucille. Lip turns it up. Shirley takes notice.
Who is this?
What?
On the radio.
Lil’ Richard. Dr. Shirley listens, surprised.
This is Little Richard?
Yeah, he’s good. Think you could play somethin’ like this, Doc?
(of course he could) I don’t know. Sounds very complicated. Shirley lowers his book.
So where did this “Tony the Lip” moniker come from?
Not Tony the Lip. Tony Lip--it’s one word. I got it when I was a kid. My friends said I was the best bullshit artist in the Bronx. (CONTINUED)
Lip smiles into the rear-view mirror.
Why are you smiling?
Huh?
You don’t mind that your friends-- the people closest to you--consider you a liar?
(offended) I never said liar, I said bullshit artist.
What’s the difference?
I don’t lie. I’m just good at, you know, talking people into doin’ things they don’t wanna do. By bullshittin’ ‘em.
And you’re proud of that? Lip shrugs, smiles.
Well it got me this job.
The Caddy whips by.
Slow Twistin’ by Chubby Checker plays on the radio. Lip i looking back at Shirley, annoyed.
You’re full of shit! You never hearda Chubby Checker?
Of course I’ve heard of him, I just never heard his music. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
But I like this. He’s got a silky voice... smooth.
This is what everyone dances to now --
Eyes on the road please. Lip flips the station. Aretha Franklin’s Won’t Be Long PL
How about this? You know this song.
I don’t think so... Lip looks back at Dr. Shirley in disbelief.
How could you not know this music? Chubby Checker, Lil’ Richard, Sam Cooke, Aretha--these are your people! Shirley wears a strained smile.

Lip and Shirley's car, followed by Oleg and George’s car, pull into the gas station and parks. Lip gets out, Shirle waits in the car, window open. Lip walks to the novelty shop, which has an outside porch area with multiple displays, knick-knacks, etc. One of th boxes is filled with an assortment of POLISHED STONES of various shapes, sizes, and colors. Lip goes to the box of stones, picks up a few, checks the out, puts them back. Oleg WATCHES AS Lip spot a large JADE-COLORED STONE on th ground. He picks it up, looks it over... Puts it in his pocket... ON DR. SHIRLEY’S CAR - MOMENTS LATER Oleg speaks to Shirley through the back window. Lip exits store, lights a smoke, heads toward Shirley's Cadillac. O goes back to his car. Lip gets in, starts the car. (CONTINUED)
Before we pull out, Tony, we need to talk. I just heard something that disturbed me a great deal. I gave you petty cash.
Yeah, so?
Oleg told me what you did.
What I do?
You stole a jade stone from the store.
No I didn’t.
He watched you do it.
I didn’t steal no stone.
You picked it up and you put it in your pocket.
Yeah, I picked a rock up off the ground--I didn’t steal one from the box.
Why would you pick up a rock off the ground?
‘Cause that ain’t stealin’. It’s just a regular rock.
(frustrated) But why would you want a regular rock?
(searching) I don’t know, just to have. Like for good luck maybe. (CONTINUED)
A lucky rock? Let me see it. Reluctantly, Lip pulls out the JADE STONE.
I want you to go back and pay for it. Lip is embarrassed, angry.
I told you that Kraut was a sneak. Rats me out for something I didn’t even do.
Pay for the stone, Tony, you’ll feel better.
I feel fine, and I’m not paying for no regular rock I found in the dirt. Lip PUTS THE CAR IN DRIVE.

Do not drive, Mr. Vallelonga. Lip stops, puts it in park. They sit in silence. Finally. Lip gets out, SLAMS the door, storms off. Shirley waits. few moments later, Lip gets back in the car, throws it in drive.
Feel better?
No.
Tony, if you’d like, I will happily buy you that stone.
Don’t bother. You took all the fun out of it. As Shirley’s Cadillac pulls back onto the highway, we go.
Shirley’s Cadillac pull in front. Lip gets out.  46.

Excuse me... I’m with the band.
You’re all set up.

That’s it.
This isn’t a Steinway...?
So what?
Dr. Shirley only plays on Steinway-brand pianos. It’s in his written contract.
Who's Dr. Shirley?
Dr. Shirley--the Don Shirley Trio?
Does it really matter?
Yes, it does. It’s in his contract. The Stage Manager rolls his eyes. (CONTINUED)
Come on, what’s the difference -- these coons can play on anything. CLOSE ON OLEG AND GEORGE as they stop what they’re doing take notice. BACK ON Lip as he looks closely at the filthy piano.

Dr. Shirley’s fingers tinkle the ivories on a Steinway, performing “HAPPY TALK” to a sold-out house. CLOSE ON THE WING OF THE STAGE where Lip is listening to music, satisfied. The Stage Manager stands a few feet bac from him, looking sheepish and a little scared.

June was a good person--terrible grammar, but a kind soul. Unfortunately, I didn’t have the constitution to do a husband act as well as a concert pianist act. I couldn’t balance both worlds.
ANGLE ON Kentucky Fried Chicken sign, then we...PAN to th Caddy approaching.

Who you bullshittin’? You people love the fried chicken, the grits, the colored greens...I love it, too. The negro cooks used to make it when I was in the army.
You have a very narrow assessment of me, Tony.
(pleased) Yeah, I’m good, right?
What? No. No, you’re not good, you're bad. I’m saying, just because other negro people listen to a certain kind of music doesn’t mean I have to. Nor do we all have to eat the same food. (CONTINUED)
Lip looks Lip holds Lip takes Lip takes 52. at Shirley in the mirror. LIP (CONT’D Whoa, wait a minute. If you said all guineas like pizza and spaghetti and meatballs, I’m not gonna get insulted.

Oooh, I’m gonna get grease on my blankie--have a piece. It ain’t gonna kill ya. a piece of chicken, holds it out to Shirley.

No.
I’m gonna throw it in the back seat.

Tony, it’s George! Wake up! Hurry up! Lip gets up, opens the door. It’s George, sweating and ou breath.

George and Lip hustle down the street.

A shit-hole. Drunken REDNECKS surround an EVEN DRUNKER Shirley. LAUGHING as they shove him, smack him around.

What the good goddamn we got here, fellas?
Hand him over, we walk out, won’t be a problem.

This boy’s gonna get what’s coming to him, and you ain’t got no say! Lip calmly reaches behind his back, under his suit jacket (CONTINUED)

And I won’t be having none of this come to pass in my place. Let the spook go. I want these Yanks off my property. I don’t understand you, Doc, honest to God. Why couldn’t you just drink here--you got a whole bottle?
I needed some air.
Air?! Don’t you know where you are? Shirley looks at him oddly.
Does the geography really matter?
What?
If I walked into a bar in your neighborhood, would this conversation be any different? Lip dodges the question.
From now on you don’t go nowhere without me. Nowhere!
Tony...Do you really have a gun?
‘Course not. Now get some rest. You got a big show tomorrow night. Now where’s your room doc? Shirley points, Lip helps Doc to his room.

Shirley's Cadillac passes a BILLBOARD that reads: “WELCOM RALEIGH - HOME OF THE N.C. STATE UNIVERSITY WOLFPACK”
Lip and Shirley drive along looking through bug-smeared windows. Miles and miles of SWEET POTATO fields.
(struggling; slow) “Betty bought... a bit of buttah... but she found the buttah bittah...”
Not buttah... butter. Say the “er.”
“So Betty bought a bit of better butter to make the bitter butter better...”
“So Betty bit a buttah...”
Don’t be lazy--enunciate. “So Betty bought a bit of better butter...”
“So, Betty bit a better buttah--” this is bullshit.

No, you need to start somewhere. Athletes stretch to warm up before an event. A singer does vocal exercises. These drills will strengthen your speech muscles. WE HEAR A NASTY “PING” FROM THE ENGINE O.S. STEAM rises f under the hood, splashes against the windshield.

The Caddy pulls over and Lip steps out into the blazing s Heat waves ripple off the scalding asphalt. Lip removes h jacket, tosses it onto the front seat. He rolls up his sleeves, lifts the heavy Cadillac hood. (CONTINUED)

Shirley rolls down the back window, observes dozens of BL WORKERS laboring in the sun. Men, women, children, bent to the waist, filling woven baskets with sweet potatoes. Shirley steps out of the Cadillac, walks to the front of car where Lip is thigh-deep under the hood. While Shirley leans on the fender, Lip walks to the trunk pulls out a jug of water and a rag. He goes back to the engine, opens the hot radiator cap, pours the water in. Dr. Shirley wipes the sweat beads off his forehead with h suit-pocket handkerchief, looks out onto the fields. One by one the Pickers STAND UP and STARE BACK AT HIM fro BOTH sides of the road. They’ve never seen a black man li him before. Lip crawls out from under the hood, wipes his hands with cloth. He notices the Pickers staring at Shirley. Lip SLAMS the hood, gets in the car. Shirley takes a reflective BEAT... follows.
CLOSE ON a stuffed-shirt, MORGAN ANDERSON, 50s, standing the veranda.

Ladies and gentlemen, our very special guest from the far north... Don Shirley! APPLAUSE. PULL BACK TO REVEAL an elite Southern crowd surrounding him. CLASSICAL MUSIC drifts from the stereo inside. BLACK WAITERS carry trays filled with champagne a hors d’oeuvres. ANGLE ON a wide-eyed Lip standing with Shirley, Oleg, and George. MORGAN ANDERSON (CONT’D) Accompanying Mr. Shirley, the members of his trio... (reading a small program) Oleg Malakhov, George Dyer, and his associate, Tony Vallla... Valleg...Valle... (CONTINUED)

Shirley, embarrassed, shoots Lip a vague I-told-you-so lo Lip shrugs, he’s not helping. MORGAN ANDERSON (CONT’D) Valley...lohnja. Lip smirks as the PARTYGOERS CLAP. Afterwards, Anderson t back to Oleg and George. MORGAN ANDERSON (CONT’D) Gentlemen, if you don’t mind, I’m going to steal Donnie away for some introductions. As Anderson walks Shirley into the house, Oleg and George grab glasses of sugared bourbon and mingle. Lip looks aro takes it all in. A WAITER approaches with a tray.
What’s this?
Pimiento-cheese sandwich, sir. Lip takes one off the tray, tries it.
Oot. Lip SPITS INTO A NAPKIN, plops the BALLED-UP NAPKIN ON TH TRAY.

Guests sit around an immense dining table. Lip sits betwe the Well-Coiffed Woman and an Elderly Woman. Dr. Shirley in the seat of honor to the right of Mr. Anderson, at the head of the table. White-gloved BLACK WAITERS place sterling-silver-covered platters down the length of the table.

Earlier this week, we asked our help what Mr. Shirley might like for supper. So the boys in the kitchen whipped up a special menu in honor of our guest. They lift the platter covers, revealing: Corn on the cob, baked beans, collard greens, grits, and the main course.. (CONTINUED)

Lip shoots Dr. Shirley a look... See? MORGAN ANDERSON (CONT’D) Don, I do hope you enjoy it! Dig in, everyone! Shirley nods and bites his tongue as a Waiter piles fried chicken onto his plate. WE HEAR THE BEAUTIFUL CHORDS OF “WATER BOY” as...
The Don Shirley Trio gives a magnificent performance of t biggest hit. As Shirley finishes the song, the room ERUPT APPLAUSE. Dr. Shirley bows.
Thank you...thank you. We will return after a brief intermission.
Shirley walks down the hall. He sees a bathroom and start ENTER.
Excuse me, Don! Shirley turns to see Anderson coming down the hall. MORGAN ANDERSON (CONT’D) Lovely work in there!
Thank you.

Are you looking for the commode? Here, let me help you. He leads Shirley to a back door, opens it. MORGAN ANDERSON (CONT’D) It’s right out there ‘fore the pines. Shirley looks out, sees an old OUTHOUSE at the edge of th woods.
I’d rather not use that. (CONTINUED)
Don’t be silly, Don. It looks a lot worse from the outside.
I understand. But I’m not going in there. There’s an awkward standoff.
I could go back and use the facilities at my motel, but... that’s going to take at least a half an hour. Anderson considers this for a BEAT, then gives a friendly smile.
We don’t mind waitin’.

head_text.subj: THE CADDY WHIPPING DOWN A COUNTRY ROAD.

text: Shirley stews in the back seat.
Why don’t I just pull over--you can piss in the woods?
Animals go in the woods.
But it’s twenty minutes if we go back to your motel.
So let’s just get there so I can go back and finish the show.
Ayyyy-. See, that’s the difference between you and me. I’d have zero problem goin’ in the woods.
I’m aware. (CONTINUED)
Lip glances in the mirror.
Why you sore at me? I don’t make the rules down here.
No? Who does? Lip gets the subtext.

Ay are you sayin’ that just ‘cause I’m white and they’re white? That's a very prejudice thing you just said there, a very prejudice thing. I got more in common with the hymies at Second Avenue Deli than I got with these hillbilly pricks down here.
Eyes on the road.
You know, you always say that when you don’t like what I’m saying.
Eyes on the road.
Show's over, GUESTS are departing. As Dr. Shirley accepts congratulations out on the steps, Lip stands by the Cadil smoking with George.
How does he smile and shake their hands like that? If they tried to pull that outhouse shit with me, I'd piss right on their dining room floor.
Don’t do that... Oleg hears this, approaches.
We have many concert dates left. (CONTINUED)
Yeah...?
You realize we are contractually obliged to play them?
Of course I do. If he don’t play ‘em, I don’t get paid. What’s your point? Oleg lights a butt.
Ugly circumstances are going to happen again... so control yourself. Lip kicks his cigarette out in the dirt.
Don’t lecture me, you rat.
Dr. Shirley could've stayed up north getting rear-end kissed at Park Avenue parties for three times money, but he asked for this.
Why? Oleg takes a pull off his cigarette, walks away.
EXT. STUCKEY’S RESTAURANT - SOUTH CAROLINA - DAY Lip and Dr. Shirley sit at a table outside. Lip eats pota chips as he WORKS ON A LETTER. Shirley can see that he’s struggling.
What on God’s green earth are you doing?
A letter.
Looks more like a piecemeal ransom note. (CONTINUED)
Shirley holds his hand out.
May I? Lip reluctantly hands him the letter.

(reading aloud) “Dear, Dolores--I’m meeting all the highly leading citizens of the town, people who use big words, all of them, but you know me, I get by, I’m a good bullshitter.” (to Lip) Two “t"s in “bullshitter.” (continues reading) “As I’m writing this letter, I’m eating potato chips and I’m starting to get thirsty. I washed my socks last night and dried them on the TV. I should have brung the iron." (to Lip) You know this is pathetic, right? Lip shrugs, embarrassed.
Tell me what you’re trying to say. Lip looks up.
(embarrassed) I don’t know. Just... you know, how I miss her and shit.
Then tell her that. But try to say it in a manner that no one has ever said it.
Shit...
And without profanity. Shirley gives the letter back to Lip, then starts to pace (CONTINUED)
Put this down. “Dolores, when I think of you, I’m reminded of the beautiful plains of Iowa.” Lip stares at him.
Put it down. Lip starts to write.
(repeating) “When-I-think-of-you-I ’m-reminded- of-the-beautiful..." Lip looks up.
Plains of Iowa.
What planes?
The plains. P-L-A-I-N-S. Those big fields we saw.
Oh, those were nice. (writing) “,..plains of Iowa--which is what they call big fields around here.”
(annoyed) Tony, no expounding. Lip looks up, confused.
No what?
Just write what I say. Shirley keeps pacing as he thinks.
“The distance between us is breaking my spirit... My time and experiences without you are meaningless to me.” (CONTINUED)
Lip writes feverishly to keep up.
(repeating) “,..Are meaningless to me.” Lip starts to write again.
Now this... “Falling in love with you was the easiest thing I have ever done.” Eyes glued to the page, Lip SCRIBBLES AWAY FURIOUSLY.

“Falling in love with you was the easiest thing...” (looks up, smiling) This is very fucking romantic. As Lip continues writing, we go... INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Dolores sits on the couch reading the letter, the kids as next to her... In her head, she HEARS LIP’S VOICE.
Nothing matters but you. I am the luckiest man alive, and every moment I am without you, I realize this. Dolores can barely believe the poetry pouring out of her husband.
I loved you the day I met you, I love you today... Dolores is PRACTICALLY IN TEARS and we go... BACK ON SHIRLEY AS HE FINISHES DICTATING THE WORDS.
Is it okay if I say, “P.S., kiss the kids”? Shirley breaks from his trance.
(CONTINUED)
Yeah, at the end.
That's like clanging a cowbell at the end of Shostakovich’s 7th. Lip nods as if he knows what Shirley’s talking about.
(hopeful) So it’s okay? Dr. Shirley can’t say no to the child in front of him.
It’s perfect, Tony. Lip smiles and writes...

Lip and Shirley walk down the street. They pass by a MEN’ CLOTHING STORE and Shirley stops to look in the window. ANGLE ON STORE WINDOW -- a WHITE MANNEQUIN dons a high-en British-style suit and vest.
That guy looks just like you, Doc.
He does?
(realizing) Size-wise. Shirley studies the suit, considering it.

Go in and try it on. What, you always gotta wear a tux on stage? Mix it up a little. INT. MEN’S CLOTHING STORE - DAY - MOMENTS LATER As Lip and Shirley ENTER, a couple BUSINESSMEN are trying suits. A TAILOR approaches Lip.
May I help you, sir? (CONTINUED)
We want to try on that suit in the window.
Of course. The Tailor pulls a suit off the rack, hands it to Lip.
Dressing room’s in the back, sir. Lip hands Shirley the suit.
Thanks. I’1l just be a moment.
Take your time. I’1l check out some ties for ya. The Tailor REACTS, follows Shirley toward the dressing ro
Uh, excuse me, you’re not allowed to try that on.
I beg your pardon? The Tailor takes the suit from him.

If you would like to purchase it first, we'll be happy to tailor it to your needs. Shirley stares at him a moment, gets it, and heads for th ANGLE ON Lip at the tie rack, watching all this. Frustrat he glares at the Tailor and follows Shirley out.
The Don Shirley Trio is in top form as they finish playin spirited rendition of BLUE SKIES. The song reaches a crescendo, the crowd BURST INTO APPLAUSE, and we

INT. LIP’S HOTEL ROOM - NIGHT Lip’s in the BATHROOM washing his socks in the sink. WE H ALFRED HITCHCOCK PRESENTS coming from the 0.S. TELEVISION THE PHONE RINGS O.S. Lip goes to the bed, passing the television. WE SEE black socks hanging on the rabbit ears antenna and some underwe drying on the vents of the TV. Lip answers the phone.
Yeah...
Lip enters the YMCA.
Lip approaches POLICEMAN #1 standing beside a swimming po
I got a call about Dr. Shirley.
Come on... Lip follows the Policeman.

Policeman #1 enters the locker room followed by Lip. Dr. Shirley, BRUISED, is handcuffed, sitting on the floor naked (also seen from the side). His skin still wet from steam room and sweat. Next to him also naked and cuffed t the radiator, is a WHITE MAN. Policeman #1 walks Lip over to POLICEMAN #2, African American.
This is him.
Can you give the guy a towel, for Chrissakes? No one moves. Lip grabs a towel off a rack and throws it Shirley, who covers himself as best he can.
You a lawyer? (CONTINUED)
No.
Well you should call one. We’re taking your Auntie in.
For what?
Manager caught him and the other guy... The Cop motions to the Caucasian Man in cuffs. Lip glances over at the dazed and humiliated Shirley. BEAT.
Can’t we get the cuffs off him, let him put his pants on?
Sure we can. But we ain’t.
Look, we’re out of here in the morning, you'll never see us again. There’s gotta be a way to work this out. (scrambling) What if, uh, you let him go, and I give you something to thank you?
You bribing us?
No, no... a thank you.
What kind of thank you?
Like... a donation to the police force. To you guys. Whatever you want. (thinks ) You like suits? (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
I was walking through your nice town today, I saw a store that was selling suits. Nice suits. The cops glance at one another.
How about, as a thank you--a donation--I buy you guys each a suit? You get dressed up nice, take your wives out to dinner. Guys like you, you deserve it. The two Policemen glance at each other.
Shirley trails Lip as they EXIT the YMCA and walk toward parking lot. No one speaks. Then...
(subdued) They were wrong for the way they treated me, and you rewarded them. We see that Shirley’s eye is bruised, his lip slightly swollen.
I was hired to make sure you get from one show to the next. How I do it shouldn’t matter to you.
I just wish you hadn’t paid them off.
I did what I had to do. You know, if this got out it would kill your career.
Okay, Tony, quit your phony altruism and concern for my career.
What the hell does that mean? (CONTINUED)
You were only thinking about yourself back there, because you know if I miss a show, it comes out of your pocket.

Of course I don’t want you to miss a show, you ungrateful bastard! You think I’m doing this for my health?! Tonight I saved your ass, so show a little appreciation. Besides, I told you never to go nowhere without me!
(calmly) I assumed you would want this to be the exception. Lip gets in the car without opening Shirley’s door. Shirl stands alone a moment, then opens his own door.
The Cadillac drives past a WELCOME TO TENNESSEE sign.
Shirley’s Cadillac pulls up. The windows are closed.
Lip and Shirley sit for a moment. It’s clear they haven’t spoken for a while.
(re: bruises) Should I try to find you some make- up or somethin’ before the show?
I’m fine.
You sure?
I said I’m fine.  76.
Lip gets out of the car, opens Shirley’s door.
Tony Lip! Lip turns to see TWO NEW YORK WISEGUYS standing out front waiting for their car. The mouth of the group is pug-nose DOMINIC.
Dominic. The hell you doin’ here?
Brooklyn sent us down to take care of a few things. He glances at Shirley, who’s waiting by the hotel entranc
(in Italian) Who’s the eggplant? CLOSE ON - Shirley, waiting for Lip by the hotel entrance
(in Italian) I’m working for him. BACK TO LIP AND DOMINIC.
(in Italian) What’d you lose a bet? One of the wiseguys LAUGHS.

(in Italian) What’s wrong with you? You need work, you come to me! I’ll always find work for you. Matter of fact, I can use you this week. Gotta hit a few joints, straighten some people out--you’ll make some real money.
(in Italian) I’m making money. (CONTINUED)
(in Italian) Whatever he’s paying you, I’1l double it. Lip glances at Shirley.
(in Italian) This isn’t the place to talk about it.
(in Italian) Meet me in the bar at eight o’clock sharp. Forget this guy.
A concerned-looking Don Shirley sits in front of the mirr in his room. He takes make-up from a SMALL KIT and dabs a his lip and bruised cheek.
Dominic sits at the bar, having a drink. Wiseguy #1 enter walks over to Dominic.
I just called his room. He’1l be down in a minute.
Lip comes out of his room, locks his door.
Where are you going? Lip turns to see Shirley behind him in the hallway.
Oh. Hey. Just... downstairs. For a drink.
(in Italian) To meet your friend, Dominic? (CONTINUED)
Lip is taken aback.
(in Italian) Before you decide whether or not to take him up on the job offer, I think we should have a word. Lip realizes that Shirley understood the earlier conversa
(in English) Tony, I think you’re doing a wonderful job. Lip shrugs, not used to Shirley being so solicitous.
So I would like to formally offer you the position of my road manager. With the title comes more responsibility and, of course, there will be a raise in pay. Lip thinks about it.
No, thanks. Shirley nods, disappointed.

You and me, we agreed on a hundred and twenty-five a week, plus expenses. That’s our deal. I ain’t goin’ nowhere, Doc. I’m just goin’ down to tell ‘em. A surprised Shirley watches Lip walk to the stairway.
Tony... Lip stops, looks to Shirley.
Sorry about last night. Lip nods. (CONTINUED)
Don’t sweat it. I been workin’ nightclubs in the city my whole life...I know it’s a complicated world. As Lip heads downstairs, WE PUSH IN on Shirley.
Dr. Shirley and Lip sit at a table in the lobby. Shirley pours them both a drink from a bottle of Cutty Sark.
So, how'd you learn how to play so good, Doc?

My mother. She taught me how to play on an old spinet. Soon as I could walk, we’d travel around the Florida panhandle and I'd put on little shows in parishes and halls. A man who had seen me play arranged for me to study at the Leningrad Conservatory of Music.
So that’s where they taught you all them songs you play?

Actually, I was trained to play classical music. Brahms, Franz Liszt, Chopin--it’s all I ever wanted to play. (smile fades) But I was persuaded by my record company to pursue a career in popular music instead. They told me audiences would never accept a black pianist on the classical stage. Wanted to turn me into just another “colored entertainer.” You know, the guy who smokes while he’s playing, who puts a glass of whisky on the piano and then gets mad when he’s not respected like Arthur Rubinstein. Well, you don’t see Arthur Rubenstein smoking and putting a drink on his piano. (CONTINUED)
Personally, if you stuck to that classic stuff I think it would’ve been a big mistake.
A mistake? Performing the music I trained my entire life to play?

Trained? What are you, a seal? Anyone can sound like Beethoven or Joe Pan or them other guys you said. But your music, what you do, only you can do, and nobody can train for that. Shirley thinks about this.
Thank you, Tony. (beat) But...not everyone can play Chopin...not the way I can.
The weather has cooled. Lip sits on a bench SCRIBBLING wh a bundled-up Shirley paces and WAXES POETIC.

(dictating) “,..The trees have shed their leafy clothing and the colors have faded to grays and browns, but my heart bursts with reds and blues and greens from the love I hold inside for you...” INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - NIGHT Dolores reads the letter ALOUD to Louie’s wife, Lynn, and Johnny's wife, Fran. In the b.g., we see the guys--Grandp Nicola and Anthony, Louie, Rudy, Johnny--at the kitchen t PLAYING CARDS.
(reading aloud) “It's getting colder as we travel, but the country is still beautiful. (MORE ) (CONTINUED)
I saw millions of trees, all dusted with snow, just like out of a fairy- tale...” Lynn and Fran are enthralled.
He’s so expressive. Dolores smiles proudly.

“We've only a few more shows before our Christmas concert in Birmingham, Alabama on the 23rd. I will count the hours, minutes, and seconds until you are in my arms. I love and miss you more than I can explain. Tony. P.S.--Kiss the kids.” CLOSE ON THE GUYS playing cards in the kitchen. They coul help overhearing Dolores.
Gotta admit, Lip’s letters--they’re not bad.
Well, it’s in the family. They say we had a great, great, great grandfather helped Da Vinci with the Sixteen Chapel.
You mean Michelangelo.
Right. And that’s a true story, right, Pop?
What the hell’s that got to do with writin’ letters?
I’m just sayin’, we’re an arty family. Frances yells to John.
John, I want a letter. (CONTINUED)

Yeah, soon as you make a meal... As the guys CHUCKLE, Shirley’s song “THE LONESOME ROAD” begins PLAYING, and we go to... A MONTAGE OF THE NEXT COUPLE WEEKS... --Shirley’s Cadillac barrels down a southern highway. The bare trees along the road show SIGNS OF THE COMING WINTER

text: --LIP AND SHIRLEY’S CAR STOPPED AT A LIGHT. A car pulls up next to them. The COUPLE inside, 30s, star stir, as they notice that Lip, a white man, is chauffeuri black man. The couple gawks rudely at them. Lip looks ove smiles, and FLIPS THEM THE BIRD.
(admonishing) Tony... As they drive off, we ANGLE ON Shirley, who cracks a tiny --SHIRLEY’S CADILLAC DRIVES THROUGH A RURAL LANDSCAPE DUS WITH SNOW.
