IT IN, THE TREE LIGHTS UP.
--A MAN IN A WHITE TUXEDO INTRODUCES DON SHIRLEY TO A SMA

text: Let’s give a fine Louisiana welcome to Don Shirley and the Don Shirley Trio! The GROUP gives him rousing APPLAUSE.
Rain pounds the pavement, THUNDER. The Cadillac’s HEADLIG fight to cut through the darkness.  83.
THE TORRENTIAL RAIN HAMMERS THE ROOF OF THE CAR. Visibili is zero, the wipers aren’t helping. Frustrated, Lip wipes windshield with his hand.
Your mother’s ass... Through the rear window, A PAIR OF HEADLIGHTS. Shirley lo back. THE CAR FOLLOWS THEM.

head_text.subj: LIP STEPS ON IT. THE LIGHTS FROM THE TAILING VEHICLE GET
LIP FLIPS UP THE REAR-VIEW TO CUT THE GLARE.

text: ‘Hell’s this guy doin’? SUDDENLY RED LIGHTS FLASH.

STEADY RAIN... Shirley's Cadillac pulls over, stops. The Highway Patrol Car tucks in close behind them. TWO HIGHWAY PATROLMEN IN RAIN GEAR exit their cruiser, approach Shirley’s Cadillac, shine FLASHLIGHTS into it.
PATROLMAN #1'‘s flashlight beams through the driver’s win almost blinding Lip. A tap on the window. Lip opens it.
License and papers?
Glad to see you guys. I’m a little lost. Lip hands Patrolman #1 his papers. ANGLE ON Shirley sitting quietly in the back as PATROLMAN 20s, fresh-faced, shines his flashlight through the windo
(to Lip) Step out of the car.
In the rain? What I do? (CONTINUED)
Out of the car. Patrolman #1 opens the door, Lip gets out. Lip stands in the dark, muddy road, the red police lights flickering off his drenched face. PATROLMAN #1 (CONT’D) Why you on this road?
I told you, I had to detour and I’m lost. We’re not from around here.
No, you ain’t. So I’m gonna ask you again... what the hell you doin’ out here? (glances at Shirley) And why you driving him? Patrolman #2 keeps the light shined on Dr. Shirley.
He’s my boss. The Patrolmen look at one another.
He can’t be out here at night. This is a sundown town.
What’s that mean?
(to Patrolman #2) Get him out of the car. Check his I.D.
Come on, it’s pouring. The young Patrolman looks to his senior partner.
I can just get it through the window.
Get him out the goddamn car! (CONTINUED)
Patrolman #2 opens Shirley’s door.
Out. Shirley gets out in the rain. Patrolman #1 studies Lip’s license.
What’s this last name say?
Vallelonga.
‘Hell kind of name is that?
Italian.
Oh, now I get it. That’s why you driving this boy around... you half a nigger yourself.
(shaking) Hands in the air, now!
Lip sits on a concrete slab in a small cell. Shirley peer through the bars out at Patrolmen #1, #2, and the grizzle POLICE CHIEF, 50s.
Excuse me! (no response) Excuse me, sirs. I quite understand why my associate is being held, but what exactly am I being charged with? Not a glance in his direction. (CONTINUED)
You seem like reasonable men--can you let me out so we might discuss the situation please?
Put the apple butter away, boy--you ain’t goin’ nowhere no time soon. Dr. Shirley’s demeanor hardens.
You cannot hold me without cause!
I got cause. ‘Cause you let the sun set on your black ass! The Chief LAUGHS.
I want to speak to a lawyer, I want my phone call! This is a flagrant violation of my rights! I demand my phone call immediately! The younger officer looks to the Chief, uncomfortable.
He does have...rights. The Chief glares at him. Finally, the Chief looks at Patrolman #1.
Give the negra his goddamn call. Reluctantly, Patrolman #1 goes to the cell, unlocks it, w Shirley to a side office. The cop picks up the phone, holds it out to Shirley.
You know a lawyer? Call him. As the cop steps away, Shirley pulls a SMALL BLACK BOOK o of his jacket pocket, flips to a page, DIALS...
Lip sits on the floor, stone-faced. Shirley paces the roo increasingly annoyed.
As my mother always said, “What kind of brand new fool are you?!” Lip doesn’t respond.
Look out there, Tony. Take a good look at the officer you hit. Lip doesn’t move.
Look at him. Lip raises his eyes. HIS POV - Patrolman #1 is sitting in the bullpen, drinkin coffee, horsing around with the other cops.

He’s having a grand old time, chatting up his pals, having a nice cup of coffee. And where are you? In here. With me. Who did nothing. Yet I’m the one who’s paying the price. I’m the one who’s going to miss the Birmingham show.
Hey, I’m losin’ a lot of money, too, if you don’t play Birmingham. Shirley steps in front of Lip.

So your little temper tantrum...was it worth it? (beat) You don’t win with violence, Tony, you win when you maintain your dignity. Dignity always prevails. And tonight, because of you, we did not. The station PHONE RINGS and Patrolman #2 answers.
Mayersville Po-lice. (CONTINUED)
The young cop STRAIGHTENS UP, color draining from his fac PATROLMAN #2 (CONT’D) (into phone) No, sir. Not me, sir. Yes, sir, he’s right here, sir. He holds the phone out to the Chief.
What? The rookie is too stunned to speak. Finally, the Chief gr the phone.
Chief Pratt--who’s this? (beat) Bull-oney. Patrolman #2 waves frantically and the Chief starts to sw He stands, starts to pace.

Okay, yes, now I hear it, Governor. I’m sorry. Yes, of course I recognize your voice. (shrinking) I-I’'m sorry, you sayin’ the boy we got locked up called who, sir? (beat) And he called you? The rattled Chief glances at Shirley and Lip--who the hel are these guys? We HEAR the 0.S. Governor SCREAMING AT HI over the phone.

But an officer was assaulted in the line of... (backing down) No, no, I don’t want no National Guard down here, neither, sir. (wilting) Yes, Governor, immediately. And good night to you and the missus. The Chief hangs up, turns to Patrolman #1.
Let ‘em go.
What?! (CONTINUED)
Cut ‘em loose, goddamnit! ANGLE ON SHIRLEY and a STUNNED LIP watching all this.
But that dago-wop hit me!
Now! BACK ON COPS - Defeated, Patrolman #1 hurries over to the cell, opens it up. Lip turns to Shirley, amazed.
Who the hell’d you call?
The Cadillac FLIES PAST a sign reading: “WHITES ONLY WITH CITY LIMITS AFTER DARK.”
Lip wears a mad, shit-eating grin as he drives through th SLASHING RAIN on the way out of town.
Bobby Kennedy just saved our asses! Maddon...How great is that?!
It’s not great--it’s not great at all--it’s humiliating. Lip glances in the rear-view.
‘The hell you talking about? We were screwed and now we ain't.
And I just put the Attorney General of the United States in an incredibly awkward position.
So what? That’s what the guy gets paid for. What else he got to do? Shirley glares at Lip. (CONTINUED)

That man and his brother are trying to change this country--that’s what else he’s got to do! Now he thinks I’m garbage. Calling from some backwoods swamp jail, asking if he can help attenuate assault charges... who does that? Garbage, that’s who. This stings Lip.
You_shouldn’t have hit him!
I didn’t like the way he was treating you, making you stand out in the rain.
Please. You hit him because of what he called you. I’ve had to listen to that kind of talk my entire life, you should be able to take it for one night.
What, I can’t get mad when he says that stuff ‘cause I’m not black? Christ, I’m blacker than you. Shirley REACTS to this.
You're blacker than me?
You don’t know shit about your own people! What they eat, how they talk, how they live--you don’t even know who Lil’ Richard is!
So knowing who Little Richard is makes you blacker than me? I wish you could hear yourself sometimes, Tony--you wouldn’t talk as much. (CONTINUED)

Bullshit! I know exactly who I am. I’m the guy who’s lived on the same block in the same Bronx my entire life, with my mother and father and my brother, and now my wife and kids. That’s it--that’s who I am. I’m the asshole who’s gotta hustle every goddamn day to put food on my table. You? Mr. Big Shot? You travel around the world and live on top of a castle and do concerts for rich people! I live on the streets, you sit on a throne--so yeah, my world is way more blacker than yours!
Pull over.
What?
Pull! Over!
I ain’t pullin’ over!
Lip steers the car to the side of the road. Shirley opens door, gets out in the rain. Lip looks out the window as Dr. Shirley walks down the drenched, muddy road.
What are you doin’?! When Shirley doesn’t stop, Lip gets out, hustles after hi
Get back in the car! Shirley keeps walking. Lip catches up, grabs his arm. Shi turns, his face drenched... (CONTINUED)

Yes, I live in a castle! Alone. And rich white folks let me play piano for them, because it makes them feel cultured. But when I walk off that stage I go right back to being another nigger to them--because that is their true culture. And I suffer that slight alone, because I’m not accepted by my own people, because I’m not like them either! So if I’m not black enough, and I’m not white enough, and I’m not man enough, what _am I?!

Tony doesn’t know what to say. They stand in the rain whi Shirley tries to compose himself. Lip awkwardly touches Shirley's shoulder. Shirley turns and walks back to the c leaving Tony standing alone in the downpour.
Back on the road, both of them disheveled and wiped out f the evening. Nobody speaks for a while.
I need sleep.
Okay, I’11 pull over at the next place we see and I’1l sneak you into my room.
No. No. I refuse to stay at an establishment that doesn’t want me.
Okay. Lip picks up the Negro Moterist Green book from the seat to him.
CLOSE ON A COLOREDS ONLY sign out front of a ramshackle b building. PAN TO the Caddy pulling into the DIRT PARKING LOT full o puddles and BEAT-UP CARS.  93.
Lip lays in a sunken twin bed in his t-shirt and underwea WRITING A LETTER. Shirley, in silk pajamas, folds his clo and places them into his suitcase.
You realize you're going to be home before that letter gets there?
Yeah, I was gonna just bring it with me. Save on stamps. Shirley rolls his eyes.
Give it here, I'll fix it. Shirley reaches for the letter, but Lip pulls it away.
No offense, Doc, but I think I got the hang of it. For a moment, Shirley's offended. Then he SNATCHES THE LE out of Lip’s hand.
(reading) “Dear Dolores, sometimes you remind me of a house.” Shirley glances at Lip... what the hell?
(reading) "RK house with beautiful lights on it where everyone inside is happy.” Shirley hands the letter back to Lip.
Yeah, you got it. Shirley gets in bed, tries to sleep. We hear O.S. cars; occasionally a dog barks in the distance.
Doc...
Yes? (CONTINUED)
Thanks for helping me with the letters--you’re really good at writin’ ‘em. (beat) Maybe when you get home you should write one to your brother?
He knows where I am if he wants to reconnect. Lip nods. He puts his letter down, turns out the light.
Don't wait for him, Doc. This I know...the world’s full of lonely people afraid to make the first move. Shirley thinks about this, then rolls over.
You know, something’s been eating at me the whole trip.
Hmmm?
That Tittsburgh was a real disappointment. I didn’t notice any difference at all.
Good night, Tony.
The Caddy motors by on its way to Birmingham.
Shirley's Cadillac drives through the city.  95.

A BANNER across this large wooden hotel reads: “CHRISTMAS CONCERT TONIGHT -- DON SHIRLEY TRIO”. THE CADDY PULLS UP FRONT AND PARKS. Lip and Shirley get out. Waiting for them is GRAHAM KINDE 40s, blue blazer, pressed slacks, friendly as hell.
(deep southern accent) Welcome, Mr. Shirley! Graham Kindell, I’m the general manager. So nice to meet y'all!
Thank you, Mr. Kindell. This is Tony Vallelonga.
Pleasure, Tony. Right this way.

Lip and Shirley (carrying his tux) follow the affable Kin through the large working kitchen. COOKS, BUSBOYS, DISHWASHERS, ALL BLACK. They continue down several busy hallways to a backstage dressing room.
If you need anything--anything t’all--you let me know.
Thank you.
Kindell leads Shirley and Lip into the modest room. A sma table, one chair, a mirror.
Here you are. We have about an hour before show time. Any questions?
Where’s the restaurant?
Continue down the hall, Tony, to the right, across the lobby. (CONTINUED)
Kindell EXITS.
We’ve got an hour. I’m starving.
Go ahead. I’1l meet you there.

A cavernous DINING ROOM/HALL. Ornately decorated in red a green ribbons and wreaths. A twenty-foot Christmas Tree towers behind the Trio’s instruments onstage. Filling in with well-dressed WHITE CUSTOMERS. Lip ENTERS, sits at a table. HIS POV - Across the room, Oleg and George eat dinner, dr wine. George CALLS OUT:
Tony! George waves him over. Lip joins them.
Shirley’1l be here in a minute. A WAITER approaches.
Cocktails, gentlemen?
Three shots vodka. Tony looks at Oleg.
Last show. Cold war over. Time for truce. Lip nods, smiles. The Waiter leaves to get the drinks.
Is Shirley in his dressing room?
More like a broom closet. I don’t understand why he puts up with this shit. Oleg takes a sip of wine, glances at George. (CONTINUED)

Six years ago, 1956, Nat King Cole was invited to perform at Municipal Auditorium right here in Birmingham. Mr. Cole was very first negro asked to play at a white establishment in this city. Lip butters a roll, takes a bite.
Soon as Mr. Cole started playing, a group of men attacked him for playing white people’s music. Pulled him off stage and beat him badly. Lip stops chewing.

You asked once why Dr. Shirley does this? I tell you. Because there is no genius without courage. 97. The Waiter returns with the drinks. They CLINK glasses, d the shots. Lip NOTICES Shirley (now in his tux) and the MAITRE D’ ha a conversation at the entrance. Lip walks over.
What’s the problem?
This gentleman’s saying I can’t dine here.
(to Maitre D’) No, you don’t understand, this guy's playing here tonight--he’s the main event. MAITRE D’ I’m sorry. It’s the policy of the restaurant. Graham Kindell, the congenial GM, joins them.
Everything all right? (CONTINUED)
No, it’s not all right. Dr. Shirley's being told he can’t eat here.
(to Shirley) I apologize, but these are... long- standing traditions. I’m sure you understand.
No. I don’t. In 45 minutes I’1l be entertaining your guests up on that stage, but I can’t eat here? Graham Kindell shifts uncomfortably.
Wait a minute. You’re tellin’ me the bozos in his band, and the shlubs that came to see him play can eat here, but the star can’t? Customers take notice. It’s getting embarrassing.
I’m afraid not. Lip looks to the stoic Shirley, then back to Kindell, searching for a compromise.
Well he’s gotta eat. Can you at least bring him food from the restaurant to his dressing room?
Of course. We’ll be happy to send him anything he would like. (to Maitre D’) John, show him a menu.
No. I’m not eating in a dressing room. There's a brief standoff. (CONTINUED)
Okay... if you’d prefer, there’s a very popular establishment right down the road--the Orange Bird-- they'll be happy to feed you. Lip turns to Shirley.
Food’s probably better there anyway --the dinner rolls here are like rocks. Come on, we can be back in 45 minutes. When Shirley doesn’t respond, Lip pulls him aside.
Doc, it’s the last show. Let’s just get through this and we can go home and get away from all these assholes. Dr. Shirley thinks about it.
No. Not this time. I’m eating in this room or I’m not playing. Kindell’s frustration grows.
(to Lip) May I have a word with you? Lip follows Kindell through a door, into a side parlor.
Kindell tries to pour on the Southern charm.
Mr. Villanueva, you have to talk sense to Mr. Shirley. Please explain that we’re not insulting him personally, this is just the way things are done down here.
Yeah, well he ain’t from down here. (CONTINUED)
Just ask him to be reasonable. I have 400 guests out there who expect to be entertained tonight.
And Dr. Shirley expects to eat tonight. Why can’t you just make an exception this one time? Kindell SIGHS.

Lemme tell you a story. You ever hear of the Boston Celtics basketball club? Those boys came through here a couple years ago on a barnstorming tour. Now, seeing as they were World Champions of the league and all, we was tickled to have ‘em eat here and we rolled out the welcome wagon. So you know what table their big coon ate at that night?
No.
I don’t either. But it wasn’t one of ours. Kindell drops the genteel demeanor.
Now let’s cut the bullshit. Tell me what it’s gonn’ take. Kindell takes out his wallet.
Say one hundred dollars and you get your boy to play? The veins on Lip’s neck rise.
You think you can buy me?
All do respect, sir, but you wouldn't be doing a job like this if you couldn’t be bought. (CONTINUED)
Lip GRABS Kindell by the collar, raises a fist.
Stop! They turn to see Shirley in the doorway. Graham Kindell p away from Lip, fixes his collar.

It’s all right, Tony. I’1l play... if you want me to. Graham Kindell SIGHS, clearly relieved. Lip is relieved, But only for a moment. Something comes over him. He glanc at Kindell, then back at Shirley. Lip finally sees the bi picture, and realizes that, for him and Shirley, this is moment of truth. Then...
Nah, let’s get the fuck outta here.
Lip escorts Shirley through the crowded ballroom toward t exit with Graham Kindell on their heels in a panic.
Don, don’t do this! Shirley and Lip keep moving at a brisk pace through the surprised and bewildered crowd.

We have a contract, and I know you're the kind of man that honors a contract! ANGLE ON the BLACK SERVERS watching their boss grovel. Th maintain deadpan expressions, but we can see the APPROVAL THEIR EYES.
You got a show to do, mister! Scattered BOOS and CATCALLS from the diners as the FURIOU Graham Kindell follows them out the front door...
They pull onto the street and drive in silence, both in s about what just happened. Shirley looks at Lip in the rea
You hungry?

This is a Blues Bar/Restaurant. Lip and Shirley ENTER. A small BAND in the corner--piano, drums and guitar--plays BLUES. Lip’s the only white guy in here and he doesn’t go unnoticed, especially standing next to Shirley in a tuxed They make their way to the bar, sit. A female BARTENDER g Lip the once-over.
You a cop?
I look Irish? She smirks.
What you want, baby?
Two Cutty’s, neat. Shirley takes out a BIG WAD OF CASH. A couple DRUNKS at t bar take notice.
Comin’ up. She grabs a bottle of Cutty, pours the drinks.
Whatever your specialty is, we’ll take it. She CALLS back toward the kitchen:
Two orange birds!
Lip and Shirley are devouring two barbecue chickens, thei hands and faces covered in orange sauce.

I like what you did back there, Doc. You stood up for yourself. It’s like your friend the President says -- “Don’t ask what your country can do for you, ask what you can do for yourself.” Shirley smiles. The Bartender approaches.
(to Shirley) So, darlin’, what you do, all dressed up like that? He shrugs.
Nothing important.
He’s only the greatest piano player in the world. She smiles.
That right? You good?
Don’t be shy, Doc. Tell her who you are.

Don’t tell me nothin’--show me. Shirley thinks a moment, glances at the BEAT-UP PIANO. He gets up, walks to the stage, sits at the piano. He notice drink on the top of the piano. Shirley takes the drink, p it on the floor. SHIRLEY PLACES HIS HANDS ON THE KEYS, TAKES A MOMENT... And then... Shirley starts to play. This isn’t a catchy j solo or a Christmas ditty. It is, instead, an explosion o sound, the eye-popping machinations of Chopin’s Etude Op. No. 11, one of the most difficult piano solos ever writte The crowd lower their forks and gaze up in disbelief. (CONTINUED)

ANGLE ON Lip watching this in awe. Black kitchen workers stop what they’re doing to watch. A COOK steps out of the kitchen, wiping his hands on his ap BACK ON SHIRLEY as he negotiates the eight-finger chord combinations with the mastery of the maestro that he is. He builds and builds and builds until his fingers become A BLUR ON THE KEYS. Shirley FINISHES, the room is quiet. Then the place ERUPTS IN APPLAUSE! CLOSE ON Lip. He’s as blown away as the audience. Shirley looks toward a stunned Lip and winks. The GUITAR PLAYER, DRUMMER, and SAX join Shirley on the stage. They start a cool up tempo rockin’ blues number. Shirley effortlessly joins in, taking the music to anothe level. The entire room begins to PULSATE. The crowd eats up. Shirley plays as if Little Richard had taken over his bod Obviously this man can play anything. A true musical geni ANGLE ON Lip as he looks on, really getting into it. BACK ON SHIRLEY, the happiest we’ve seen him.
An exhausted Shirley and Lip are dragging themselves acro the parking lot toward the Cadillac.
If we leave right now, I think you can make it.
Make what?
Christmas Eve. Lip stops walking, holds his hand in front of Shirley. Li reaches behind his back, PULLS OUT A GUN, SHOOTS INTO THE AIR. (CONTINUED)
ON CUE, one of the runks from the bar, knife in hand, jum out from BEHIND THE CADDY and SPRINTS OFF, followed by th other drunk. THEY HIGH-TAIL IT OUT OF THERE. Shirley look Lip, shocked.
Don’t ever flash a wad of cash ina bar. As Lip walks to the car...
I knew you had a gun!
The Cadillac breezes down the highway in a light rain.
A LIGHT SNOW flicks against the windshield. Lip checks ou the ominous sky.
This could get bad.
Yes, it’s a shame we don’t have something to protect us on our journey. Dr. Shirley thinks, then SNAPS his fingers.

Why don’t you put your lucky rock up on the dash, Tony? Lip stares at him in the mirror for a LONG BEAT. Finally, reaches in his pocket, pulls out the JADE STONE THAT WE THOUGHT HE HAD RETURNED, places it on the dash.
Thank you. I feel safer already. Lip wears a tiny smile.
You're a real prick, you know that?  106.
It’s SNOWING HEAVILY now and conditions have worsened. Th Caddy is one of the only cars on the road.
The Caddy passes by, BLOWING UP A SHEET OF SNOW.
Lip squints, trying to focus, WIPERS FLAPPING VIOLENTLY, visibility awful.
Doc, my eyes are stingin’, I might need to pull over.
Keep going as long as you can, Tony.
The lonely Cadillac fights through the NORTHEASTER as conditions get more and more treacherous.
A tense-looking Lip struggles to keep the car on the road SUDDENLY A BLUR OF RED LIGHTS FILLS THE CAR FROM BEHIND. glances in the mirror.
Shit...
The Cadillac pulls over in the slush, a MARYLAND STATE PO CAR right behind it.
An annoyed Lip sits waiting for the Cop. A LIGHT beams through the window. Lip rolls it down, revealing a MARYLAND STATE TROOPER.
What are you doing out here? (CONTINUED)
We're trying to get to New York. The Trooper flashes his light on Shirley in the backseat.
Is there a problem, Officer? TENSE BEAT, THEN...
Yeah. I noticed your car was tilting to the left. Looks like your back tire’s flat. Lip opens the door, glances back at the snowy flat tire.
The State Trooper DIRECTS TRAFFIC SAFELY AROUND THEM as L jacks up the car in the storm.
Lip SHUTS THE TRUNK and gets back in the car. The Trooper approaches his window.
Okay... be careful, gentlemen. Merry Christmas. This is the first flicker of humanity they’ve experienced a while. As the Trooper walks away, Lip and Shirley glanc each other, smile.
The Caddy drives through a blizzard.
Lip blinks repeatedly as he tries to concentrate on the r From the 0.S. RADIO, we HEAR: (CONTINUED)

“Weather advisory warning this Christmas Eve, aS a major snowstorm is hitting the eastern seaboard with the severest weather in eastern Pennsylvania, northern New Jersey and the five boroughs. Travelers are advised to stay off the Jersey Turnpike, as well as the bridges and tunnels leading into New York City, due to possible road closures...”
That’s it. I’m pulling us into the next motel.
Keep going, Tony, you can make it.
I can’t keep my eyes open, Doc--I’m gettin’ hytnotized by the snow. I think my brain’s gonna explode. As we PUSH IN on a disappointed Shirley, we...
INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - NIGHT
“HAVE YOURSELF A MERRY LITTLE CHRISTMAS” FROM THE FRANK SINATRA CHRISTMAS ALBUM plays on a record player.
“Have yourself a merry little Christmas...” The tiny apartment is filled with CHRISTMAS DECORATIONS,

head_text.subj: CHRISTMAS LIGHTS AROUND THE WINDOWS, A SMALL CHRISTMAS TR
WITH TWINKLING LIGHTS IN THE CORNER.

text: The dining room table has been moved into the living room accommodate all the guests. Grandpa Anthony, Grandpa Nicola, Rudy, Louie with his wif Lynn and their baby, Johnny with his wife Fran, their two little DAUGHTERS, and Nick and Frankie. (CONTINUED)

Everyone’s in good cheer, talking, drinking wine, eating appetizers. Dolores is busy putting platters of THE FEAST THE SEVEN FISHES, all fish dishes cooked Italian style, o table. Stuffed Calamari, Baked Clams Oreganata, Fried Fil Sole, Fried Calamari & Shrimp, Linguini with Clams, etc. KITCHEN - Dolores moves into the kitchen, now alone. She braces herself on the counter, tries not to cry...

SNOW AND SLEET POUND THE EMPTY STREETS. The snowflakes reflect red, white, and green from the lights that adorn buildings. There’s not a moving vehicle in sight. Then... IN THE DISTANCE, one lonely set of CAR LIGHTS appears. PU IN SLOWLY, SLOWLY until the lights get closer and we can OUT that it’s THE CADDY.

Lip’s STRETCHED OUT in the back seat, SLEEPING. PULL BACK reveal DR. SHIRLEY AT THE WHEEL, FOCUSING INTENTLY. We can HEAR the 0.S. SOUND of the CADILLAC’S WHEELS SPINN as Shirley negotiates the slippery streets.
Lip still sleeping in the back seat. He’s jolted awake by someone BANGING on the window.

Tony, wake up! THE SNOW CONTINUES TO FALL... The Caddy is parked in fron Lip’s apartment building. Shirley stands on the sidewalk, Lip’s bag on the ground beside him. Shirley opens the bac door. Lip looks up, groggy. He realizes he’s home.
What... Doc, whadja’ do? Shirley helps Lip climb out of the car. He hands Tony his suitcase.
You’re home. Go inside.
Doc, why don’t you come up, meet my family...? (CONTINUED)
Merry Christmas, Tony. Shirley gets in the car. Lip’s stunned, this can’t be how ends.

Doc, wait up! Hey... Lip watches as the car drives off, the tail-lights of the Caddy disappearing into the snowy night. INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Jimmy Roselli’s “BUON NATALE (MEANS MERRY CHRISTMAS TO YO PLAYS on the stereo. Dinner is winding down. Everyone at table is stuffed and having a festive time, except...

Dolores, who fights the good fight for her guests. THE KITCHEN - Dolores comes in, starts putting dirty plat in the sink... She HEARS A COMMOTION coming from the livi room... THE LIVING ROOM - Everyone jumps up from their seats as L ENTERS, brushing snow off his coat, singing an Italian so

Hey, look who it is--Shakespeare’s home! The kids run into their father’s arms. Everyone crowds ar Lip, hugging, kissing... Dolores enters from the kitchen, stands watching... Dolores and Lip gaze at each other... She moves to him, w her arms around his neck, they kiss. The family breaks in applause.
You hungry?
You kiddin’? I’m starving. They all laugh, sit at the table.
We can barely see the building through the snowfall.  111. INT. SHIRLEY’S APARTMENT - NIGHT - MOMENTS LATER Shirley ENTERS his apartment, followed by his valet, Amit who carries Shirley’s luggage.
Welcome home, Dr. Shirley.
Thank you, Amit.
I turned down your bed, sir. Will you be needing anything else?
No, thank you. Go home to your family.

Thank you, Doctor. Merry Christmas. Amit EXITS. Suddenly SHIRLEY IS ALL ALONE. He glances aro his apartment at the throne, the elephant tusks, all his possessions. The room is quiet. Dr. Shirley reaches in his pocket, takes out the JADE STO He PLACES IT ON HIS MANTEL, next to some other artifacts.

INT. LIP’S APARTMENT - LIVING ROOM - NIGHT Lip and stuffed picking talking the entire family are at the table. Lip has an over- cannoli in front of him while everyone else is away at a large assortment of desserts. Everyone’s except for Lip, who seems happy but distant.
Tony, s’matter with you? You haven't said a word.
Yeah, sorry, just tired. Long trip. (under breath, to Johnny) You take care of that thing?
Yeah, yeah. He pulls something out of his pocket and hands it to Lip UNDER THE TABLE. (CONTINUED)
ANGLE UNDER THE TABLE - we see that it’s Tony’s WRISTWATC Lip puts the watch on.
Thanks.
You owe me seventy-five bucks. Lip REACTS.
Charlie said sixty.
What, I’m doing this for nothin’? Lip shoots Johnny a look.
Hey, Lip, tell us about the trip.
Yeah. So how was he, the tootsune? He get on your nerves? Lip shoots him a look.
Don’t call him that. Rudy’s taken aback. Embarassed.
Okay... ANGLE ON DOLORES watching this. She looks surprised by Li reaction to the slur. A pleasant surprise. The family’s surprised too. Everyone’s quiet. Dolores changes the subj
Tony, you should’ve seen the day last week when Frankie grabbed onto the TV and climbed up on it! I took a picture...
Are you nuts, Dee? With all those tubes back there, and the cord--he could've got electrocuted! (CONTINUED)

You’re thinkin’ of toasters. No one’s gettin’ electrocuted from a TV. As everyone starts to ARGUE about toasters and TVs, there KNOCK ON THE DOOR. Lip gets up, goes to the door. He open it, REACTS. Charlie from the pawn shop stands in the doorway with his wife, Marie.
Charlie!
Hey, Lip. Johnny invited me.
Come on in.
You remember Marie.
Hi, Marie, Merry Christmas. Johnny gets up from the table, greets Charlie and Marie.
Charlie, you came? I was kidding? And you brought the wife, too? He takes them to the table.

Hey, everybody, Charlie from the pawn shop. Can you believe it? Christmas, he didn’t bring nothing! Charlie, I’m kidding, sit down... Lip turns to shut the door and sees - Dr. Shirley, standi in the doorway, holding A BOTTLE OF CHAMPAGNE, looking unsure. Tony Lip smiles and hugs him, walks him in. Lip turns to family, excited.
Everyone, this is Dr. Donald Shirley! (CONTINUED)

Merry Christmas. REVERSE ANGLE reveals Johnny, Nicola, Rudy, Louie, Anthon everyone... watching them, STUNNED AND SPEECHLESS. No one budges. Shirley smiles nervously. LONG BEAT. Then finally Johnny stands.
Well, come on, make some room! Get the man a plate! Dolores approaches Shirley.
You must be Dolores. She smiles and he hands her the champagne.
Buon Natale. Thank you for sharing your husband with me. Lip smiles. Dolores hugs Shirley and WHISPERS in his ear.
And thank you for helping with the letters. Shirley, surprised, laughs. CLOSE ON DOLORES - She smiles, and we -- CUT TO BLACK.

Dr. Donald Shirley continued to tour, compose, and record was awarded the Isaac Stern Medallion, and was the only o Carnegie studio resident, besides Leonard Bernstein, who performed annually at Carnegie Hall. During his prolific career, he composed three symphonies, piano concerti, a cello concerto, three string quartets, one-act opera, a symphonic tone poem based on Finnegan's Wake, and a set of "Variations" on the legend of Orpheus the Underworld. (CONTINUED)

Frank “Tony Lip” Vallelonga went back to his job at the Copacabana, eventually becoming Maitre’ D, until its clos in 1973. It was at the Copa where he met Francis Ford Coppola, who cast him in a small role in The Godfather. This led to an impressive acting career, including roles in Raging Bull, Pope Of Greenwich Village, Donnie Brasco, and Goodfellas. Lip is best known for his portrayal of New York crime bos Carmine Lupertazzi in the HBO series The Sopranos. Tony Lip and Dr. Shirley would remain lifelong friends un their deaths within months of each other in 2013.
